comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  it('middle-click closes tab', function()
```
is this relevant to this test?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -184,4 +184,29 @@ describe('tabline', function()
     ]],
     }
   end)
+
+  it('middle closes tab', function()
+    insert('tab1')
+    command('tabnew')
+    insert('tab2')
+    command('tabprev')
+    api.nvim_set_option_value('tabline', '%1T口口%2Ta' .. ('b'):rep(38) .. '%999Xc', {})

comment_data.body: why? (the comment should give a hint about why, also)
use a blank line to separate this "group" of code, just like the other cases in this same function

use naming conventions that match surrounding code, if not the entire codebase
```suggestion
void do_tabclose(int c1)
```

I understand that it's supposed to close the tab, despite the current mode.
AFAIK there is no specific behavior regarding middle mouse clicking on a tab in a specific mode.
Please, correct me if I'm wrong :)

why not move this code: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/ce5a9bfe7e537c81d34bd4a27fc6638f20114e67/src/nvim/mouse.c#L413-L414

_after_ this code:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/ce5a9bfe7e537c81d34bd4a27fc6638f20114e67/src/nvim/mouse.c#L476

and put the middle-click handling in there (line 476)? 

special-casing stuff in random places makes the logic very hard to follow.

`<MiddleMouse>` can have mode-specific mappings like any other keycode. So I don't see why it ignore modes. OTOH, this might be moot, see https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/27522#discussion_r1493824043

Oh, i see.
Then it would be better to enclose the "click on tab with middle mouse to close" scenario, so it would be still be able to work on mode-specific mappings.
Great catch, thank you.
It is not, I believe I found a better way to test this.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
static void do_tabclose(int c1)
```

```suggestion
        case kStlClickTabClose:
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
          return true;
```

Nit: doesn't matter here since middle mouse in insert mode (where `start_arrow()` applies) puts instead, but maybe it's best to stay consistent with the other code that returns `true` below?

This function name is confusing as there is already a `:tabclose` Ex command. I think the function name should contain the word "mouse". Its position in the file is also strange. I think it should be after `move_tab_to_mouse()`.
Agree, would `mouse_tab_close()`  be more suitable?
Middle mouse button clicking on what?

comment_data.body: I think this function should be moved below `move_tab_to_mouse()` so that it is grouped with more similar functions.

comment_regular_data.body:
@justinmk I manage to reduce the amount of failing tests (8 to 2) given that the mod keys + middle click experience was affected.
Yet I can manage to find a way to fix this test:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/ce5a9bfe7e537c81d34bd4a27fc6638f20114e67/test/functional/ui/mouse_spec.lua#L502
Also the test workflow is a bit confusing, so I'm not entirely sure what the test scope is supposed to be.
Do you have any context on this?
I believe every other scenario is fixed.
thanks!

> Also the test workflow is a bit confusing, so I'm not entirely sure what the test scope is supposed to be.

That test is checking whether `%@` items in a custom `'tabline'` ("execute function labels" in `:h 'stl'`) receive the middle mouse click events. Because your changes close the tabpage when that happens, the label's execute function isn't receiving the event anymore.

~~You may want to check that `tab_page_click_defs[mouse_col].type != kStlClickFuncRun` in your condition (maybe `!= kStlClickDisabled` too?)~~ Zeer's solution below addresses it best :point_down:

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(tabline): middle mouse button now closes tab
